titleproper.value:
Guide to the Simon W. Gerson Papers
                    <num>TAM.330</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Peter Meyer Filardo and Jennifer Jana

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T19:29-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Simon W. (Si) Gerson, 1909-2004, was the longtime New York State, and later national legislative/political action director for the Communist Party, and was an advocate of proportional representation and ballot access for minor political parties, including in the 1980s-90s as a leader of the Coalition for Free and Open Elections (COFOE). He served as Confidential Examiner to Manhattan Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, 1938-40, managed Communist election campaigns (later writing a biography 
                <emph render="italic">Pete: The Story of Peter V. Cacchione, New York's First Communist Councilman</emph>), and organized activities in support of the Communist Party leaders indicted under the Smith Act, as was Gerson. In the 1950s he was executive editor of the Party's newspaper, the 
                <emph render="italic">Daily Worker</emph>, and of its later successor, the 
                <emph render="italic">Daily World</emph>. Along with his wife, Sophie Melvin Gerson, an organizer of the Gastonia Textile Strike of 1929, he was a longtime resident of and community activist in the Bensonhurst neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York. The papers contain clippings, correspondence with leading communists and political figures, published and unpublished writings including manuscripts, memorandums, newspaper columns, reviews and reports, a scrapbook and speeches, including materials relating to Cacchione's career and death, and to Gerson's several campaigns for public office, research notes and typescript drafts for several chapters of a never-completed book, "Do We Really Have Free Elections (ca. 1990)," a related manuscript by Adam Lapin, "Tweedledum and Tweedledee: The American Two Party System," Communist Party internal documents, including reports by leading figures, many relating to the communist political crises of 1956-58 and 1989-91, and minutes of and correspondence relating to COFOE and the publication 
                <emph render="italic">Ballot Access News</emph>.

<list>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="bold">Simon W. Gerson Selected Bibliography: Monographs and articles in periodicals (excluding book reviews and newspaper articles). Arranged chronologically</emph>.</item>
                    <item>------, "A People's' Constitution for New York." New York State Communist Party, n.d.</item>
                    <item>The New Left Social Fascism. 
                        <emph render="italic">Communist</emph>, 9 (July, 1930): 622-631.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">It Is Happening Here</emph>. New York: New York State Committee, Communist Party, 1941.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">Public Speaking: A Speakers Guide Book</emph>, by Peter V. Cacchione; foreword by Simon W. Gerson. New York : Workers Library Publishers, 1942.</item>
                    <item>Thomas E. Dewey: His Record. 
                        <emph render="italic">Communist</emph>22 (May, 1943): 461-468.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">Pete Cacchione--His Record</emph>. New York: Workers Library, 1943.</item>
                    <item>The Stork Club Goes for Dewey. 
                        <emph render="italic">New Masses</emph>60, no. 11 (Sep 11, 1946): 17-20.</item>
                    <item>How You Can Beat Dewey. 
                        <emph render="italic">New Masses</emph>61, no. 6 (November 5, 1946): 4-5.</item>
                    <item>Electoral Coalition Problems. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>, 26 (October, 1947): 894-901.</item>
                    <item>La Guardia: Guerrilla Warrior. 
                        <emph render="italic">New Masses</emph>(October 7, 1947): 9-12.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">The Killing of William Milton</emph>, by Art Shields, Introduction by Simon W. Gerson. New York: 
                        <emph render="italic">Daily Worker</emph>, 1948.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">Either the Constitution or the Mundt Bill: America Can't Have Both</emph>. New York: New Century, 1950.</item>
                    <item>The Jury System and Democratic Rights. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>, 31: 35-44 (July, 1952).</item>
                    <item>The Outlook for the N.Y. City Elections. New York State Communist Party (1954).</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">The Rights You Save May Be Your Own</emph>. New York: New York State Communist Party, 1954.</item>
                    <item>A Communist at Cornell. 
                        <emph render="italic">Masses & Mainstream</emph>, 8 (July, 1955): 28-35.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">Pete: The Story of Peter V. Cacchione, New York's First Communist Councilman</emph>. New York: International Publishers, 1976.</item>
                    <item>On Building a Mass Anti-monopoly Party. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(October 1977): 22-26.</item>
                    <item>
                        <emph render="italic">After Fifty Years: Revisiting the U.S.S.R</emph>. New York : NWR Publications, 1978.</item>
                    <item>The 1978 Midterm Elections. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>57, no.1 (January, 1978): 18-21.</item>
                    <item>Vito Marcantonio: From Republican to Radical. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(November, 1979)</item>
                    <item>Independence and Coalition; The Communist View. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(December, 1979): 7-12.</item>
                    <item>From Truman Doctrine to Reagan Doctrine. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(August, 1987): 15-21.</item>
                    <item>How to Win Political Democracy. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(November, 1985): 14-17.</item>
                    <item>“Does the U.S. Have Free Elections?” 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(December, 1990): 10-14.</item>
                    <item>Again, on Political Independence. Si Gerson and Jarvis Tyner. 
                        <emph render="italic">Political Affairs</emph>(January, 1993): 41.</item>
                </list>

Notable individuals represented include: Ann Rosenhaft and Richard Winger (COFOE), Irving Adler, Helen Alfred (Peace Publications), Zaccariah Chafee, Mike Davidow, William O. Douglas, Harry Eisman, Fred Fine, William Z. Foster, Gil Green, Dorothy Healey, Murray Kempton, James Jackson, Al Lannon, Robert Minor, George Morris, Otto Nathan, Joseph North, John Pittman, Al Richmond, Lester Rodney, Morton Sobell, Norman Thomas, Robert Thompson, Carl Winter, and Alden Whitman (New York Times).
